title: Strictly's Katya Jones glum after Mike Bushell got death threats
text:
Katya Jones looked downcast on Monday after it emerged her dance partner Mike Bushell has been subject to death threats.

The Russian choreographer, 30, was pictured leaving a restaurant in London's Covent Garden on her own amid backlash over last week's Strictly Come Dancing result.

Katya and Mike found themselves in the dance-off against Catherine Tyldesley and her partner Johannes Radebe but progressed to the next week whilst their co-stars were eliminated - proving to be a controversial decision.

Solemn: Katya Jones looked downcast on Monday after it emerged her dance partner Mike Bushell has been subject to death threats

Katya did not appear to be taking the backlash well as she cut a solemn figure on her solo outing.

The ballroom professional failed to raise a smile, and kept a low-profile in a long grey coat teamed with a printed top and trainers.

She was laden with luggage on the outing, possibly heading to Manchester for a week of training with Mike, who resides there to be close to the BBC Salford studios.

Solo: The Russian choreographer, 30, was pictured leaving a restaurant in London's Covent Garden on her own amid backlash over last week's Strictly Come Dancing result

Standing by him: Katya has no doubt been distressed to learn that her dance partner Mike Bushell (pictured together on Monday) has been subjected to death threats

BBC sports presenter Mike, 53, recently told of his horror as he spoke for the first time about the threat to his life on Twitter by a deranged viewer.

He was sitting on his sofa with his wife Emily at the time and was so concerned that he reported the tweet to authorities but the threat was then removed.

Mike also hit out at viewers who say the show is rigged and described the judges as 'the best in the world.'

Keeping things low-key: Katya did not appear to be taking the backlash well as she cut a solemn figure on her solo outing

Sombre: The ballroom professional failed to raise a smile, and kept a low-profile in a long grey coat teamed with a printed top and trainers

Judge Shirley Ballas left many fans fuming when her casting vote sent former Coronation Street star Catherine and her partner Johannes crashing out of the competition.

On Tuesday, Mike hit back at the 'vile' social media abuse he has suffered following the dance-off saying people need to realise that Strictly is 'an entertainment show'.

He said: 'It was on Sunday night and my wife Emily just turned to me on the sofa and said: 'Wow, someone has threatened to kill you because of the Strictly voting'.

Bags are packed: She was laden with luggage on the outing, possibly heading to Manchester for a week of training with Mike, who resides there to be close to the BBC Salford studios

'We just thought 'this is ridiculous' and we tried to report the person on social media but they then removed the tweet and then there was a lot of other vile abuse.

'And you're thinking 'this is an entertainment show and to get death threats over an entertainment show - this is ridiculous.'

'It is perfectly valid for people to have an opinion and I totally understand people saying 'Oh Catherine's a better dancer, she should have stayed in and Mike should have gone home.' I totally understand that.

Speaking out: BBC sports presenter Mike, 53, recently told of his horror as he spoke for the first time about the threat to his life on Twitter by a deranged viewer

'On the dance-off you have to trust the judge's opinion and Catherine was completely humble and gracious. We've been messaging each other with messages of support. It' nothing personal like that.

'But to have people saying 'unless you pull out they're boycotting the show or they're going to kill you' it just seemed so far and above as to be ridiculous when there are so many important issues in the world.

'This is an entertainment show. It's not rigged, the judges are the best in the world, they know what they're talking about and it was on that one dance off.'

Dance off: Katya and Mike found themselves in the dance-off against Catherine Tyldesley and her partner Johannes Radebe but progressed to the next week whilst their co-stars were eliminated - proving to be a controversial decision

Mike added that listening to criticism from judges Craig Revel Horwood and Bruno Tonioli about his bottom sticking out helped him win the dance-off.

He said: 'With the dance-off you think this is your last chance, your last chance saloon.

'The dance-off is a funny thing - it is like a penalty shoot out and so I put everything into it.

'I listened to what Craig said, I listened to what Bruno said about my bottom sticking out and tried to tuck it in and Katya said the dance-off was 50 time better than the main dance on Saturday night.

'We then turned to each other and said we can't do any more and it was quite a big relief.

Hitting back: On Tuesday, Mike hit back at the 'vile' social media abuse he has suffered following the dance-off saying people need to realise that Strictly is 'an entertainment show'

'You can't lose in that situation. If you go out you go out with your head held high. If you survive another week then you go through and you're very grateful for that. it's awful sending someone home that's the only thing.

'I definitely feel I upped my game on the dance-off and Catherine did as well. I couldn't call it, I'm not a technical expert at all.

'I think overall in the series Catherine is the better dancer and her and J are wonderful people, a wonderful pairing and I thought they might go all the way to the final but on the night what happens happens and one has to go home and if it's on the dance off it can be tough and it's like penalty shoot out.

'How many times have we seen bigger teams lose like when Spurs this season to Colchester in a penalty shoot out. Sometimes these things can happen.

Shock result: Viewers had expected Catherine (pictured on the show on Sunday) to win the dance-off against the BBC sports presenter

'All you can do is worry about yourself and worry about doing your best and if you've done your best that's all you can do and hen it's in the hands of the judges.

'All I can do is put the hours in and try my best and if that's good enough to get you through - fantastic. If not as long as you go home with your head held high then that's absolutely fine.'

Speaking on BBC Radio Solent on Tuesday, the station where he got his first broadcasting job, Mike said: 'The judges are like the referee, accept the decision and get on with it.

'To have that sort of abuse thrown at me, that's crazy. It's got way out of hand. Yesterday I got loads of messages of support so that was the flip side of things so that was nice. You can't get too worked up about it, you have to rise above it.'
